Some owners sold refuse slaves northward, but Northern colonies passed laws discouraging their importation, describing them as 'Som[e] Sent for murder Som[e] for thifing Som[e] Runaways & most Impudent Lame & distempred.'

instruction: How did the US use disability to exclude immigrants?
response: At Ellis Island, officials performed 'snapshot diagnoses' of 2,000-5,000 people daily, claiming to detect 'defects, derangements and symptoms of disease' from twenty-five feet away. Suspects were chalk-marked: L for lameness, X for mental illness, H for heart. The 'likely to become a public charge' (LPC) clause excluded those considered unable to perform manual labor—even when immigrants had supported themselves abroad or had job offers waiting. Deaf blacksmith Moische Fischmann had two job offers and family support, but was deported to Russia because his 'certified condition will seriously interfere with his earning capacity.' 'Poor physique' excluded those with 'frail frame' or short stature, and was also used to reject suspected 'sex perverts.' Chinese were excluded because 'there is not sufficient brain capacity in the Chinese to furnish motive power for self-government.'

instruction: What was the American eugenics movement?
response: Beginning with Indiana in 1907, over thirty states passed forced-sterilization laws targeting 'socially inadequate classes': the 'feebleminded,' insane, 'criminalistic,' epileptic, 'inebriate,' diseased, blind, deaf, 'deformed,' and 'dependent' (including orphans, homeless, and paupers). More women than men were sterilized despite the greater ease of sterilizing men. Alice Smith, committed for epilepsy at seventeen, was ordered sterilized by New Jersey's Board of Examiners of Feeble-Minded (Including Idiots, Imbeciles and Morons), Epileptics, Criminals and Other Defectives. Her 'transgressions' were racial (she'd had a child with an African American neighbor), sexual (unmarried pregnancy), and class-based (poverty). Investigators constructed four-generation 'pedigree charts' documenting the 'moral and physical defectiveness' of entire families. The experts concluded allowing her to reproduce would be 'a crime against society.'

instruction: How did industrialization create disability while defining it as personal failing?
response: US capitalism and industrialization both literally and conceptually created disability. Industrialization generated disability through dangerous working conditions, industrial accidents, and pollution-caused disease. The US industrial accident rate exceeded that of other industrial countries; during World War II, 'it was safer for Americans to be on the battlefront than to work on the home front in the arsenal of democracy.' Yet disability was legally defined as 'inability to perform manual labor'—an individual failing. This definition became increasingly gendered, raced, and class-based: it required immigrant women prove ability to labor for wages even while many native-born women were not expected to work. People with disabilities who did work were 'contradictions in terms'—they didn't fit preconceptions, so their existence was erased. The system that produced disability then blamed individuals for their conditions.

instruction: What was the experience of formerly enslaved disabled people after emancipation?
response: Freedom 'depended upon one's ability and potential to work.' Newly freed slaves eagerly sought employment and mobility—equating movement with freedom. But some literally could not leave. A postwar 1867 report noted many 'helpless' former slaves remained on plantations, unable to leave their former owners, working for food. Blind Hannah of Mississippi remained in her former owner's home, unable to leave. 'Scores of disabled slaves remained enslaved.' Meanwhile, racist medical professionals diagnosed freedom itself as causing insanity. Alabama Insane Hospital admitted emancipated people with diagnosis that 'freedom' caused their mental illness. Southern medical superintendent J.F. Miller claimed insanity and tuberculosis had been 'rare diseases among the negroes of the South prior to emancipation' and that slavery provided 'conditions conducive to physical health and mental repose.'

instruction: How did World War II change employment of disabled workers?
response: During World War II, 'when an exceptional demand for labor arose, there was a significant increase in the employment of disabled workers who compiled impressive records of productivity.' Government employment-agency placement of people with disabilities rose from 28,000 in 1940 to 300,000 in 1945; between 1940 and 1950, placements numbered almost 2 million. Employers reported 'smaller labor turnover among these workers, less absenteeism, and equal or higher production rates.' May Curtis, a deaf Gallaudet alumnus, worked on B-29 fuselages and as Pentagon typist, proclaiming 'It's not in the history books, but I'm the deaf Rosie!' But after the war, 'there is a very noticeable tendency to slight the disabled worker in favor of the worker with no disability.' The wartime experience proved disabled workers were capable; postwar exclusion revealed ableism, not incapacity, as the barrier.

instruction: Who was Paul Strachan and what was the AFPH?
response: Paul Strachan used his experience as a labor organizer to found the American Federation of the Physically Handicapped (AFPH) in 1940—the first national cross-disability activist organization. Strachan understood disability as a rights issue, not social welfare. Rather than focusing on individuals' 'adjustment' to disability, he urged policies addressing social structures that excluded people with disabilities. Disability, he argued, was a class and labor issue. He urged employment quotas (affirmative action), low-cost loans for education and housing like veterans received, and building accessibility. 'WHY is it that there still exists this unreasoning, unjust prejudice against millions of Handicapped people?' Much AFPH funding came from labor unions who knew disability was a workers' issue. By 1946 the AFPH had groups in eighty-nine cities, advocating employment rights against medical-charity approaches.

instruction: How did the Disabled Miners movement connect disability to labor struggle?
response: In 1967, disabled coal miners and widows formed the Disabled Miners and Widows of Southern West Virginia after UMWA fund trustees eliminated benefits. Robert Payne, a Black miner burned in a mine explosion, led wildcat strikes involving 40,000 miners. 'It didn't scare me and I'm still not scared, because I'm fighting for a cause,' he said of his fourteen days in prison. Coal mining was incredibly hazardous—during WWI, more miners died in southern West Virginia than US soldiers died in Europe. Serious injury rates were at least eight times the death rate; black lung disease was endemic. When working miners saw 'UMWA officials crashing through picket lines of wheelchair bound miners and old women,' they joined the strike—knowing their own risk of disability. The movement led to UMWA reform under Arnold Miller, a miner disabled by black lung.

instruction: How did the Blind Veterans Association address racism and ableism together?
response: The Blind Veterans Association, founded 1945, explicitly welcomed Black and Jewish veterans and spoke against racism and anti-Semitism—unlike the American Legion, VFW, and Disabled American Veterans which excluded African Americans or enforced segregation. When African American veteran Isaac Woodard was brutally blinded by white police while still in uniform, the BVA raised funds on his behalf. Historians argue that by wrestling with their own ableism during rehabilitation, blind veterans came to understand the connection between race and disability. As historian Robert Jefferson puts it, 'They understood race and disability to be social markers used to justify social and political inequality between groups, rather than as markers of personal tragedy.' The 1951 novel Lights Out tells this story: a white blinded veteran confronts his racism after befriending a fellow blinded GI who turns out to be Black.

instruction: What is ableism and how does it function structurally?
response: Ableism reflects fear of, aversion to, or discrimination against people with disabilities. It can be as blatant as refusing to hire someone with an apparent disability, or as subtle as assuming everyone at a concert can stand for two hours. Like racism, sexism, or homophobia, ableism is directed at individuals AND built into social structures—lived out purposefully, accidentally, and unknowingly. Ableist ideologies shape media (people with disabilities either absent or portrayed as tragic), beauty standards, definitions of dance, measures of health, and expectations for leadership. When disability is defined as 'inability to perform manual labor,' this gendered, raced, and classed definition excludes some while exempting others. When immigration officials excluded those likely to face discrimination due to disability, they used anticipated ableism to justify further ableism. The structures reproduce themselves.

instruction: How did indigenous North American peoples understand disability before European colonization?
response: Most indigenous communities had no word or concept for 'disability' as we understand it. Indigenous worldviews rested on the interwoven nature of body, spirit, and mind—an 'able body' in itself would be inconsequential because only if spirit, body, and mind were in harmony was a person considered well. Disability was defined relationally rather than bodily: it occurred when someone lacked community relationships or couldn't participate in reciprocity. A young man with cognitive impairment might be an excellent water carrier—that was his gift. If the community needed water and he provided it well, he lived as a valued member with no stigma. Limitations shaped contributions, but that was true of everyone. Indigenous families were more reluctant than other communities to hand family members to outside institutions because as long as someone sustained meaningful reciprocal relationships, they weren't considered disabled.

instruction: What was the Hiawatha Asylum for Insane Indians?
response: The Hiawatha Asylum for Insane Indians, established in 1902 in Canton, South Dakota, was the only federally operated psychiatric institution for indigenous peoples. Commitment involved virtually no legal safeguards—Bureau of Indian Affairs agents could confine anyone they chose: parents opposing boarding schools, individuals resisting assimilation, those practicing indigenous religions, or simply those considered 'bothersome.' Standards of insanity literally foreign to indigenous nations were violently imposed. Director Harry Hummer believed 'full-bloods' were more likely insane than those with European heritage. Staff cut inmates' hair—described by activist Pemina Yellow Bird as 'spiritual murder.' Most died at Hiawatha and at least 131 are buried within sight of the asylum windows. A 1929 federal inspection found 'intolerable conditions,' straitjackets, ankle chains, 'the poorest kind of medical care,' and 'conditions very much below the standard of a modern prison.' Today a golf course lies on the grounds, with the unmarked cemetery near the fifth tee.

instruction: Why was Helen Keller's political activism erased from history?
response: Helen Keller was a socialist, suffragist, and radical political activist whose political life has been systematically erased from the historical record. She testified before Congress in 1944 about the intersection of racism and ableism, condemning 'the discrimination which limits employment chances' for Black blind people: 'It is a disgrace that in this great wealthy land such injustice should exist to men and women of a different race—and blind at that!' Yet popular memory reduces her to a child who learned to communicate with Anne Sullivan—erasing decades of political activism. This erasure is itself historically significant: it shows how disabled people are permitted to be inspirational figures only when depoliticized, and how radical political consciousness gets stripped from those whose stories are allowed into the mainstream.

instruction: What happened with deinstitutionalization and how did it fail?
response: From 1965 to 1980, the number of people institutionalized in public asylums fell by 60 percent: from 475,000 to 138,000. Where before 1965 patients spent years or decades in asylums, after 1970 stays were measured in days or weeks. The lucky found support in independent-living centers or community group homes. The rest ended up homeless or incarcerated. Incarceration became the dominant method of 'care' for poor people perceived to have mental or psychiatric disabilities. A 2006 Bureau of Justice study reported more than half of all prison and jail inmates had a mental health problem—approximately 1.25 million prisoners, 'twice the number of mad citizens incarcerated in state hospitals during peak years of institutionalization in the mid-1950s.' The vast majority are poor and people of color. Deinstitutionalization was not supported by the means necessary for it to succeed—another example of how liberation without material support produces worse outcomes.

instruction: How was FDR's Warm Springs racially segregated?
response: Franklin Roosevelt founded Warm Springs rehabilitation center in 1926, and its facilities were built on universal design principles—accessible to wheelchair users. At Warm Springs no one stared; wheelchairs were routine; lifelong friendships and professional ties formed. But it was a retreat for 'an elite group of the disabled.' African Americans served as waiters and cleaning staff but were not welcome as patients or employed as medical professionals. Medical personnel throughout the country erroneously insisted that Black and Asian Americans were not susceptible to polio, justifying their exclusion. Black civil rights leaders first drew attention to Warm Springs segregation during FDR's 1936 reelection campaign. Warm Springs finally desegregated in 1945 at Eleanor Roosevelt's personal insistence—after FDR's death. Race shaped experiences of polio just as it shaped everything else: Black polio survivor Wilma Rudolph, future Olympic gold medalist, had to ride a segregated bus fifty miles for treatment.

instruction: What was the Deaf community's response to oralism and why did it matter?
response: The oralist movement of the late 19th and early 20th centuries sought to eliminate sign language and force deaf people to lip-read and speak—a policy of cultural erasure. Alexander Graham Bell was a leading oralist who advocated against deaf intermarriage. Yet deaf communities organized resistance through deaf clubs, athletic programs, drama, poetry, religious services, and advocacy organizations like the National Association of the Deaf. Sarah Uhlberg described her school's deaf community as 'our oasis of language and meaning, in the midst of the huge expanse of desert silence and incomprehension that was the greater hearing world.' Deaf people created rich linguistic communities while facing systematic attempts to destroy their language. The 1988 Deaf President Now campaign at Gallaudet University, when deaf students successfully demanded a deaf president, represents the culmination of over a century of resistance to hearing control of deaf education and culture.

instruction: What does the history of disability reveal about the construction of American citizenship?
response: As the nation experimented with democracy, political theorists contrasted 'idiots,' 'lunatics,' women, and the enslaved with those worthy of full citizenship. States developed disability-based voting exclusions alongside those of race and gender. Inherent to the creation of the United States was legal and ideological delineation of those who embodied 'ableness' and thus full citizenship. When individuals denied citizenship sought to claim it, they used the language of able-bodiedness—the 1848 Seneca Falls Convention resolved that 'the equality of human rights results necessarily from the fact of the identity of the race in its capabilities and responsibilities.' Frederick Douglass agreed 'the true basis of rights was the capacity of individuals.' Claims to citizenship required proving one was not disabled—reinforcing ableist ideology even while fighting other forms of exclusion. Disability has always been at the core of debates over who counts as a full citizen.

instruction: Why is disability pride difficult but essential?
response: As activist Eli Clare writes, 'Pride is not an inessential thing. Without pride, disabled people are much more likely to accept unquestioningly the daily material condition of ableism: unemployment, poverty, segregated and substandard education, years spent locked up in nursing homes, violence perpetrated by caregivers, lack of access. Without pride, individual and collective resistance to oppression becomes nearly impossible. But disability pride is not an easy thing to come by. Disability has been soaked in shame, dressed in silence, rooted in isolation.' Such shame, silence, and isolation have been built into institutions, laws, and the perceived and unperceived elements of US history. The most important and repeated part of the story of people with disabilities has been the effort to reclaim the body—personal, 'stolen,' national, and civic—as one's home. Making oneself at home in one's body and country requires transforming both.

instruction: What are the three stages of capital's circular movement according to Marx?
response: The three stages are: First Stage - The capitalist appears as a buyer on the commodity-market and labour-market; money is transformed into commodities through the circulation act M-C. Second Stage - Productive consumption of the purchased commodities by the capitalist. The capitalist acts as a producer; capital passes through the process of production. The result is a commodity of more value than the elements entering its production. Third Stage - The capitalist returns to the market as a seller; commodities are turned into money through C-M. These three stages form the continuous circuit that capital must traverse repeatedly for capitalist production to continue.

instruction: What distinguishes M-C in capital's circuit from ordinary commodity purchase?
response: In the circuit of capital, M-C represents not merely an ordinary purchase but the conversion of money-capital into productive capital. The sum of commodities purchased (C) equals L + MP, where L is labour-power and MP is means of production. This specific combination distinguishes it from ordinary commodity circulation because: (1) the commodities purchased must have specific use-values corresponding to the production process, (2) the quantitative relation between money spent on labour-power and means of production is determined by the surplus-labour to be extracted, and (3) these commodities are destined to function as elements of productive capital, not for personal consumption.

instruction: How does Marx distinguish between labour and labour-power to solve the Ricardian contradiction?
response: The Ricardian school collapsed on this contradiction: if labour is the measure of value, and labourers exchange their labour with capital, the exchange appears unequal - workers receive less value than they produce. Ricardo couldn't reconcile this with his law of value. Marx solved it by distinguishing labour from labour-power: it is not labour that is bought and sold, but labour-power - the capacity to work. Labour-power is a commodity with its own value (determined by the labour needed to reproduce the worker), but when consumed in production, it creates more value than it costs. There's no violation of value exchange - the capitalist pays the full value of labour-power, but gains use of labour which produces more value. This is how surplus-value originates without violating the law of value.

instruction: How does the capitalist actually 'advance' wages according to Marx?
response: Marx argues the common notion that capitalists 'advance' wages to workers is a capitalist quid pro quo (sleight of hand). In reality, the worker advances labour to the capitalist: work is performed before wages are paid. The labourer works for a week or month, creating products for the capitalist, before receiving payment. The value paid as wages already exists in the products the worker has made - the worker 'himself creates the fund out of which the capitalist pays him.' Far from the capitalist advancing anything, it is labour-power that has functioned twice: first as a commodity sold, then as productive power creating value exceeding its own cost. The money the worker receives is merely the money-form of value they themselves produced.

instruction: Why is the rate of surplus-value not affected by the proportion of fixed to circulating capital?
response: The rate of surplus-value (s/v) depends solely on the relation between surplus-labour and necessary labour - how much unpaid work is extracted relative to the value of labour-power. Whether the capitalist uses more or less fixed capital (machines, buildings) does not change this ratio. A highly mechanized factory and a labour-intensive workshop can have the same rate of surplus-value if workers in both work the same proportion of time for themselves (reproducing their wages) versus for the capitalist (creating surplus-value). The confusion between fixed/circulating and constant/variable capital led Ricardo and others to wrongly think the proportion of fixed capital affects profit rates in ways that actually derive from the organic composition of capital (c/v ratio), which Marx analyzes in Volume III.

instruction: What is productive capital and how does it differ from money-capital and commodity-capital?
response: Productive capital (P) is capital in the form that actually functions in the production process - it consists of means of production (MP) and labour-power (L) combined. Unlike money-capital (M), which exists as money capable of purchasing production elements, and commodity-capital (C'), which exists as finished products awaiting sale, productive capital is the form in which value actually expands through the extraction of surplus-value from living labour. The transformation M-C(L+MP) converts money-capital into productive capital; the production process P...C' creates the surplus-value; and C'-M' realizes this surplus-value by converting commodity-capital back to money-capital. All three forms are necessary moments in capital's continuous circulation.

instruction: Why must the circuit of capital be viewed as a continuous process rather than isolated acts?
response: Marx emphasizes that capital's circuit must be understood as a continuous, repeated process because: (1) Capital is not capital at rest but capital in motion - it must constantly pass through its metamorphoses to remain capital. (2) Viewing any single phase in isolation (e.g., M-C as mere purchase) misses its function within capital's self-expansion. (3) The circuit's formula M-C...P...C'-M' shows that the endpoint M' becomes the starting point for a new circuit - capital must be continuously thrown back into circulation. (4) Any interruption in the circuit - unsold commodities, idle money, or halted production - represents a crisis for capital. The continuous flow through all three stages is the normal condition of capitalist production.

instruction: What is circulation time and why does it represent a barrier to capital accumulation?
response: Circulation time is the period during which capital exists as money-capital or commodity-capital - the time spent buying inputs (M-C) and selling products (C'-M'). During circulation time, capital is not in production and therefore not creating surplus-value. Marx calls circulation time 'a barrier to the self-expansion of value' because every moment capital spends in circulation is a moment it could have been in production extracting surplus-labour. This is why capitalists seek to minimize circulation time through: faster transportation, telegraphs and communication, credit systems, concentrated markets, and commercial intermediaries. The contradiction is that circulation is necessary to realize surplus-value (sell products) but simultaneously limits its production.

instruction: What is the relationship between the three circuits of capital: money-capital, productive capital, and commodity-capital?
response: The three circuits represent different starting points for viewing the same continuous process: (1) Circuit of money-capital: M-C...P...C'-M' - emphasizes capital as self-expanding value, profit as the goal. (2) Circuit of productive capital: P...C'-M'-C...P - emphasizes continuous production, the repetition of the production process. (3) Circuit of commodity-capital: C'-M'-C...P...C' - emphasizes the commodity product as both result and precondition, and includes consumption as part of the circuit. Each formula illuminates different aspects: the money circuit shows capital's general formula; the productive circuit shows reproduction; the commodity circuit shows how individual capital connects to total social capital. Real capital simultaneously exists in all three forms at different stages of its turnover.

instruction: Why is it incorrect to derive profit from 'adding value' to commodities during sale?
response: Marx rejects the mercantilist view that profit comes from selling above value ('profit upon alienation' or adding value in circulation). If seller A gains by selling above value to buyer B, then B loses equally - there is no net social gain, merely redistribution. Total social surplus-value cannot originate from such exchanges because 'the capitalist class cannot cheat itself as a whole.' Surplus-value must originate in production, not circulation. Circulation merely realizes the surplus-value already embedded in commodities by transferring ownership. The exchange of equivalents in circulation (buying at value, selling at value) does not preclude exploitation - exploitation occurs because labour-power is a peculiar commodity whose use creates more value than its own value.

instruction: How does credit affect the turnover of capital?
response: Credit fundamentally transforms capital turnover by: (1) Advancing money before commodities are sold, allowing continuous production despite slow sales. (2) Enabling purchase of inputs before revenue is received, reducing the money-capital that must be held idle. (3) Concentrating the money-capital of many individual capitalists for deployment by a few, accelerating accumulation. (4) Shortening circulation time by eliminating actual money transfers (bills of exchange, bank credit). (5) Allowing expansion beyond the limits of individual capital through borrowing. However, credit also amplifies contradictions: it enables overproduction by financing production beyond effective demand, creates chains of debt obligations that collapse in crises, and transfers surplus-value from productive to money-dealing capitalists through interest payments.

instruction: What did Marx mean by saying the Ricardian school 'suffered shipwreck on the rock of surplus-value'?
response: The Ricardian school collapsed because it could not resolve two contradictions while maintaining the labour theory of value: (1) How can labour be the measure of value when living labour in exchange with capital has 'lower value' than the products it creates? (2) How can equal capitals yield equal profits when they employ different proportions of labour? Ricardo's followers couldn't explain these without abandoning either the labour theory of value or the reality of equal profit rates. Marx solved both: the first by distinguishing labour-power (a commodity with value) from labour (value-creating activity); the second by showing how competition redistributes surplus-value through prices of production (Volume III). The failure showed that bourgeois economics could not fully comprehend its own system.

instruction: What is the turnover of variable capital and why is it significant?
response: The turnover of variable capital measures how often the capital advanced in wages is returned through the sale of products. If wages are paid weekly and products sell weekly, variable capital turns over ~50 times per year. This matters because variable capital is what produces surplus-value, and faster turnover means: (1) the same advanced variable capital can employ labour more times per year, (2) more surplus-value is produced annually from the same capital advance, (3) the annual rate of surplus-value (s' × n, where n is number of turnovers) rises. A capital with v = 100 and s' = 100% turning over 10 times yields 1000 annually in surplus-value, while turning over once yields only 100 - same rate of surplus-value, tenfold difference in annual mass.

instruction: What is the relationship between surplus-value production and its realization in circulation?
response: Surplus-value is produced in the labour process (P) but realized only through sale of commodities (C'-M'). This creates a fundamental tension: production of surplus-value and its realization are separate moments that can conflict. Surplus-value exists in commodities before sale but becomes actual only when converted to money. If commodities cannot be sold - due to overproduction, inadequate demand, or circulation problems - surplus-value remains unrealized and capital accumulation is blocked. This explains why crises manifest in circulation (unsold goods, falling prices, credit collapse) even though their ultimate cause lies in production (exploitation, accumulation, disproportionality). The capitalist must be both exploiter in production and successful seller in circulation.

instruction: Why is it significant that in Department I, 4,000c is replaced entirely within the department?
response: The internal replacement of 4,000 Ic reveals that a large portion of social production never enters exchange with the consumption goods sector at all. Means of production used to make more means of production (machines to make machines, iron to make iron-making equipment, coal for iron smelting) are exchanged only among Department I capitalists. This shows: (1) Capitalism's reproduction is not simply production for consumption - much production serves production itself. (2) Department I can expand independently of workers' consumption within limits. (3) The size of Department I relative to II grows as capitalism develops and accumulates. (4) Crises cannot be explained by underconsumption alone - the vast internal circulation within Department I has its own dynamics. This internal replacement is invisible if we think only in terms of revenues and consumption.

instruction: How did Quesnay's Tableau Économique influence Marx's reproduction schemas?
response: Marx acknowledges Quesnay's Tableau Économique as 'an extremely brilliant conception, incontestably the most brilliant for which political economy had until then been responsible.' Quesnay first attempted to show the annual circulation of the social product between classes (productive agriculturalists, landlords, sterile/industrial class). The Tableau showed how the annual product must replace the capital consumed in production while also providing revenue for consumption. Marx builds on this by: (1) dividing social production by physical form of product (means of production vs consumption goods) rather than by class, (2) showing the exchange relations between departments mathematically, (3) correcting the physiocratic error that only agriculture creates surplus-value, (4) analyzing both simple and expanded reproduction. Quesnay grasped reproduction as a social process; Marx made it scientific.

instruction: What does Marx mean by 'capital in general' versus particular capitals?
response: Marx distinguishes between analyzing 'capital in general' - the essential nature and laws of capital abstracted from competition among many capitals - and analyzing particular capitals in their concrete competition. Volume I examines capital in general: the production of surplus-value, exploitation, accumulation as such. Volume II examines capital's circulation forms, still largely at the level of capital in general. Volume III introduces competition, examining how surplus-value is distributed among particular capitals through profit rate equalization, prices of production, commercial and interest-bearing capital. The reproduction schemas examine 'total social capital' - the aggregate of all particular capitals functioning as departments. This method moves from abstract to concrete, from essential determinations to their modified appearance in competition.

instruction: Why does Marx emphasize that the distinction between Departments I and II is based on use-value, not value?
response: Marx insists the departmental division is based on the physical form (use-value) of products, not their value composition. Department I produces things that must enter production (machines, raw materials, tools); Department II produces things that enter individual consumption (food, clothing, housing). This matters because: (1) Value analysis alone cannot explain reproduction - a capitalist cannot eat machines or run factories on bread. (2) The physical form determines where products can go: means of production must replace means of production consumed. (3) This shows how production for production's sake (Department I expansion) can proceed semi-independently of consumption. (4) Crisis analysis requires understanding both value relations and material replacement. Smith and Ricardo, by resolving value into revenues alone, lost sight of this material dimension of reproduction.

instruction: How does the sale of labour-power differ from the sale of other commodities?
response: Labour-power is a unique commodity because: (1) It exists only in living workers and cannot be separated from them - when labour-power is sold, the worker themselves enters the capitalist's control. (2) It is reproduced daily through workers' consumption, not produced once and stored. (3) Its use-value for the buyer is precisely that it creates value - and more value than it costs. (4) It cannot function as commodity-capital for the worker because it is not capital at all in their hands, just their sole means of livelihood. (5) Its value is determined by the labour-time needed to reproduce the worker, but its use creates value determined by how long and intensively it works. The peculiarity of this commodity - that using it produces more value than buying it costs - is the secret of surplus-value and capitalist exploitation.

instruction: What is the difference between individual consumption and productive consumption?
response: Productive consumption is consumption of means of production and labour-power in the creation of commodities - it occurs within the production process and results in products of greater value. The consumed means of production transfer their value to products; the consumed labour-power creates new value. Individual consumption is consumption of articles for personal sustenance and enjoyment - food, clothing, shelter consumed by workers and capitalists outside production. For workers, individual consumption reproduces labour-power; for capitalists, it is expenditure of revenue (surplus-value). Marx shows both forms are necessary for social reproduction: productive consumption maintains the material conditions of production, while individual consumption maintains the human bearers of social relations - workers and capitalists as classes.

instruction: What is the relationship between the annual rate of surplus-value and the rate of surplus-value?
response: The rate of surplus-value (s/v or s') measures exploitation within a single production period - surplus-labour relative to necessary labour. The annual rate of surplus-value (s' × n, where n is number of turnovers) measures total surplus-value produced in a year relative to variable capital advanced. If s' = 100% and variable capital turns over 5 times annually, the annual rate = 500%. This distinction matters because: (1) Faster turnover increases annual surplus-value from the same capital advance. (2) It explains why industries with rapid turnover can show higher annual returns despite the same exploitation rate. (3) It connects the production of surplus-value to its realization through circulation. The annual rate appears in the money-form as annual profit, relating realized surplus-value to capital advanced.

instruction: How does Marx analyze the formation of hoards necessary for accumulation?
response: Marx shows accumulation requires prior hoard-formation: before a capitalist can invest in expanded production, they must accumulate money-capital by selling without immediately buying. This hoarding occurs through: (1) Retaining portions of realized surplus-value as money rather than spending on consumption. (2) Setting aside depreciation funds from fixed capital before replacement is needed. (3) Retaining portions of circulating capital value during turnover gaps. Different capitalists are at different accumulation stages - some are hoarding (selling, not buying), others are investing hoards (buying, not selling). This creates a reciprocal flow: A's sales provide money for B's investment; B's sales later provide money for A's investment. The credit system socializes this process, concentrating individual hoards for centralized deployment.

instruction: Why is it significant that the reproduction schemas assume exchange at values rather than prices of production?
response: Marx notes that analyzing reproduction at values rather than prices of production (which include profit rate equalization) doesn't change the fundamental laws. Prices diverge from values for individual commodities, but total prices equal total values; total profits equal total surplus-value. The material requirements for reproduction - that means of production be replaced by means of production, consumption goods by consumption goods - remain regardless of price deviations. The departmental proportions I(v+s) = IIc hold in aggregate. Introducing prices of production redistributes surplus-value between capitals but doesn't alter the total or the physical replacement requirements. Volume II's value-based analysis establishes the fundamental framework; Volume III's price-of-production analysis shows how competition modifies appearances while confirming underlying value relations.

instruction: How does Marx explain the appearance that profits derive from circulation rather than production?
response: Marx shows why it appears that profit comes from selling (circulation) rather than production: (1) Surplus-value exists in commodity form before sale but is only realized as money-profit when commodities are sold. (2) The individual capitalist experiences profit as the difference between buying price and selling price. (3) Merchant's capital, which never enters production, appears to make profit purely through buying and selling. (4) Competition among capitalists manifests in circulation through price adjustments. However, this appearance is illusory: circulation can only redistribute existing values, not create new ones. Total social surplus-value equals total surplus-labour performed - it's created in production, merely realized in circulation. The merchant's profit is a share of surplus-value produced by industrial workers, redistributed through the equalization of profit rates.

instruction: What determines how long the total social capital takes to reproduce itself?
response: The reproduction period of total social capital depends on: (1) The turnover times of various individual capitals, which vary enormously by industry. (2) The proportion of fixed capital in total capital and its durability - buildings last decades, machines years, while circulating capital may turn over weekly. (3) The ratio between Departments I and II - economies with larger Department I (producing means of production) have slower average turnover. (4) The length of working periods in major industries. (5) Circulation time, affected by market distance, transportation, commercial organization. Marx notes that for social capital, simple reproduction assumes the same scale continues, but actual capitalism features constant accumulation, technical change, and shifting proportions - making 'simple reproduction' an analytical abstraction rather than empirical description.

instruction: How do Marx's reproduction schemas differ from bourgeois equilibrium models?
response: Marx's schemas analyze reproduction to reveal capitalism's contradictions, not to prove equilibrium is normal. Key differences: (1) Marx shows specific proportional conditions must be met - I(v+s) = IIc - but capitalism has no mechanism ensuring this; disproportionality is endemic, not exceptional. (2) Bourgeois models often assume Say's Law (supply creates its own demand); Marx shows production and consumption can diverge, creating crisis. (3) Marx includes class analysis - reproduction perpetuates capitalist and working classes; equilibrium models treat agents as interchangeable. (4) Marx shows accumulation necessarily disrupts any equilibrium, requiring constantly changing proportions. (5) The schemas reveal capitalism's tendency toward crises, not its tendency toward harmony. They are tools for analyzing instability, not apologetics for stability.

instruction: Why does Marx say that bourgeois economists after Smith had 'absolutely nothing to add' to his analysis of fixed and circulating capital?
response: Marx argues that Smith's confused treatment of fixed and circulating capital became dogma that his successors merely repeated without improvement. Ricardo inherited Smith's confusions and made them worse by making raw materials disappear from his analysis. Later economists like Ramsay noticed problems but couldn't resolve them because they accepted Smith's basic framework. The fundamental error - confusing the fixed/circulating distinction (about turnover) with the constant/variable distinction (about surplus-value production) - prevented understanding of capitalist exploitation. Each generation of economists repeated the mistake because correcting it would mean acknowledging that surplus-value comes from exploitation of labour, not from capital's inherent productivity. The confusion served ideological purposes even as it blocked scientific advance.

instruction: What is the role of luxury goods production within Department II?
response: Marx divides Department II into IIa (necessary means of subsistence, consumed by workers) and IIb (luxury goods, consumed only by capitalists). This subdivision reveals: (1) Workers' consumption is limited to necessaries - their wages buy only IIa products. (2) Capitalists consume both necessaries and luxuries with their surplus-value. (3) Luxury goods production (IIb) employs workers who consume necessaries from IIa. (4) Expansion of luxury production depends on growing surplus-value, not workers' consumption. (5) In crisis, luxury production can collapse without directly affecting workers' necessary consumption. The distinction shows how capitalist consumption is parasitic on surplus-value extraction, and how the structure of consumption reproduces class divisions. Workers produce luxury goods they cannot buy, while capitalists consume what workers' labour creates.

instruction: How does Marx's analysis in Volume II prepare for the transformation problem resolved in Volume III?
response: Volume II analyzes capital circulation assuming exchange at values, establishing fundamental reproduction conditions. But a puzzle emerges: equal capitals with different organic compositions (c/v ratios) would produce different amounts of surplus-value if exchanged at values. Volume III shows how competition equalizes profit rates by redistributing surplus-value through prices of production that deviate from values. Volume II's contribution is showing that: (1) the total surplus-value produced sets limits on profit - redistribution can't exceed what's created; (2) material reproduction requirements hold regardless of price-value deviations; (3) the c + v + s value structure remains fundamental even when modified in appearance. Volume II's analysis at the level of value is necessary preparation for Volume III's analysis at the level of prices of production.

instruction: What is the transformation of surplus-value into profit according to Marx?
response: The transformation of surplus-value into profit involves both a conceptual and quantitative change. Conceptually, surplus-value (the product of exploiting labour) becomes profit (apparently a product of total capital). When surplus-value is related to total capital C rather than variable capital v alone, it assumes the mystified form of profit. Marx writes that profit is 'the form in which surplus-value presents itself to view, and must initially be stripped by analysis to disclose the latter.' This transformation conceals exploitation: in the form of profit, capital appears as 'a relation to itself' generating new value, hiding the real relation between capital and labour. The further transformation into prices of production (Volume III, Part Two) shows how equal capitals yield equal profits despite different organic compositions.

instruction: What is the significance of the distinction between what a commodity costs the capitalist versus its actual cost?
response: Marx emphasizes that 'what the commodity costs the capitalist and its actual production cost are two quite different magnitudes.' The capitalist's cost (cost-price = c + v) excludes surplus-value because unpaid labour costs the capitalist nothing. But the actual cost to society is the total labour embodied (c + v + s). This distinction reveals exploitation: the difference between these magnitudes is precisely the surplus-value extracted from workers. It also explains why capitalists view cost-price as the 'true' value - from their perspective, anything above cost-price is pure gain. This appearance leads to the vulgar economic view that profit arises from selling above value, rather than from production. The distinction is fundamental to understanding how capitalism systematically conceals the source of profit.

instruction: Why can't the equalization of profit rates be explained without the labour theory of value?
response: The equalization of profit rates through competition redistributes surplus-value between capitals but cannot create new value. If profit came from anywhere except unpaid labour, its source would be unlimited and indeterminate. Marx shows: (1) Total profits equal total surplus-value - there's a definite limit set by total surplus-labour performed. (2) The redistribution through prices of production transfers value from capitals with low organic composition to those with high organic composition. (3) This explains why highly mechanized industries can be profitable despite employing little living labour - they receive transferred surplus-value. Without the labour theory, there's no explanation for what constrains total profit, why profit rates tend to equalize, or why productivity increases in one branch affect profit rates elsewhere.

instruction: What is Marx's critique of the vulgar economic view that profit arises from selling above value?
response: Marx demolishes the idea that profit comes from 'adding' to prices in circulation: If seller A sells above value to buyer B, A gains but B loses equally - there's no net gain for society. 'The capitalist class cannot cheat itself as a whole.' Profit must originate in production, not circulation. The vulgar view confuses individual transactions with social aggregates and mistakes realization of surplus-value (through sale) for its creation. Torrens and others claimed the 'natural price' (cost of production) excludes profit, which therefore must arise from exchange. Marx responds that this is 'creating something out of nothing' - transferring the mystery from production to circulation without solving it. The commodity already contains surplus-value before sale; selling merely converts this latent surplus into money-form.

instruction: What role does fixed capital play in the cost-price calculation?
response: Fixed capital (machinery, buildings, etc.) enters cost-price only through depreciation - the portion of its value transferred to products through wear and tear, not its total value. If fixed capital = £1,200 with annual depreciation of £20, only £20 enters the cost-price of annual output, while the remaining £1,180 stays in the capitalist's productive capital. Circulating capital (raw materials, wages) enters cost-price entirely since it's fully consumed in each production cycle. This distinction affects profit calculations: surplus-value relates to total capital advanced (including unconsumed fixed capital), but cost-price contains only consumed capital. This explains why capitalists with large fixed capital investments need long production runs to amortize equipment - interruptions in production mean fixed costs continue while value-transfer stops.

instruction: What is the distinction between universal labour and cooperative labour according to Marx?
response: Universal labour encompasses all scientific discovery and invention - work that depends partly on cooperation with the living and partly on utilizing the labours of those who have gone before. It is labour whose benefits extend across all of society and accumulate historically. Cooperative labour is the direct cooperation of individuals working together in a shared production process. Both contribute to production, but differently: universal labour advances through scientific and technical progress accessible to all; cooperative labour realizes these advances in specific production processes. Marx notes that 'trail-blazers generally go bankrupt' - those who first apply new inventions bear heavy costs, while later capitalists 'buy the buildings, machinery, etc. at a cheaper price' and profit from others' universal labour.

instruction: How does Marx critique Proudhon's proposal to sell commodities at their cost-price?
response: Marx shows that Proudhon's scheme to eliminate exploitation by selling commodities at cost-price is fundamentally confused. If commodities sold at cost-price (c + v), surplus-value would simply be transferred to buyers rather than eliminated. Workers would still perform surplus-labour, but for purchasers rather than their direct employers. Moreover, since different industries have different organic compositions, equal cost-price reductions would benefit different parties unequally. Proudhon's error stemmed from thinking cost-price was 'true' value and surplus-value was merely an addition in exchange. Marx responds: the 'thoughtless conception that the cost-price of a commodity constitutes its actual value' fundamentally misunderstands value creation. Exploitation occurs in production regardless of selling prices; changing prices merely redistributes surplus-value.

instruction: What is interest-bearing capital and how does it differ from industrial capital?
response: Interest-bearing capital (loan capital) is capital that obtains a return purely by being lent to another capitalist for use. The lender receives interest; the borrower (functioning capitalist) receives profit of enterprise after paying interest. Unlike industrial capital which produces surplus-value through exploitation, or commercial capital which helps realize it, interest-bearing capital appears to generate returns purely from the property relation - capital seems to make money simply by existing. Marx calls this the 'most superficial and fetishized form' of capital, where the relation M-M' (money breeding money) conceals all connection to production and labour. Interest appears as an inherent quality of money itself, creating what Marx calls 'capital fetishism' in its most complete form.

instruction: How does Marx analyze the division of profit into interest and profit of enterprise?
response: Gross profit divides into interest (paid to money-capitalists who lend capital) and profit of enterprise (retained by functioning capitalists who actually employ capital in production). This division creates the appearance that each represents a distinct source: interest seems to reward capital ownership per se, while profit of enterprise appears as 'wages of superintendence' for capitalist labour. Marx exposes both as mystifications: the total profit remains surplus-value from exploited labour, merely distributed between two types of capitalist. The functioning capitalist's 'supervision' is partly necessary coordination (which could be performed by workers themselves) and partly enforcement of exploitation. The split conceals exploitation twice over: interest-bearing capital seems to grow by its own nature, while profit of enterprise seems to be earned.

instruction: Why does Marx call interest-bearing capital the 'most complete fetish'?
response: In interest-bearing capital, the formula M-M' (money producing more money) represents capital's most mystified form because: (1) The production process disappears entirely - money appears to grow by itself without any mediation by commodities or labour. (2) Capital seems to possess an inherent self-expanding quality, as if fertility belonged to money itself. (3) The social relation of exploitation vanishes completely from view. (4) Time itself appears productive - lending money for a period generates return regardless of what happens to it. (5) Interest rates seem to determine profit rather than the reverse. Marx writes that in this form, 'the capital relationship reaches its most superficial and fetishised form' - the connection between profit and unpaid labour is buried under multiple layers of appearance.

instruction: What is Marx's theory of ground rent?
response: Ground rent is surplus-value paid to landowners for permission to use land in production. Marx distinguishes: (1) Differential rent I - arises from differences in natural fertility or location, allowing some land to yield higher output with equal capital investment. (2) Differential rent II - arises from successive investments of capital on the same land with different productivities. (3) Absolute rent - arises from landownership itself, which can keep land out of production unless rent is paid, allowing even the worst land to charge rent. Rent is not created by land but transferred from surplus-value produced by agricultural workers. Landowners receive rent not for producing but for owning a monopolizable natural condition of production. Rent represents a barrier to capital, extracting tribute from surplus-value.

instruction: How does differential rent arise from differences in land fertility?
response: Differential rent I emerges when capital is invested on lands of varying fertility while commodities sell at a price determined by the worst (marginal) land in use. On better land, the same capital and labour produce more output, but the output sells at the same price. The excess profit (above average profit) becomes differential rent, captured by the landowner. Example: if worst land yields 1 quarter of wheat per £1 invested, and average profit is 20%, wheat prices must allow £1.20 return per quarter. Better land yielding 2 quarters per £1 receives £2.40 but still needs only average profit of £0.20, leaving £1 of differential rent. Rent thus measures the difference in natural productivity between marginal and better lands.

instruction: What is absolute rent and how does it differ from differential rent?
response: Absolute rent is rent paid even on the worst land in cultivation, arising from land monopoly rather than productivity differences. Differential rent transfers surplus-profit from better lands to landowners; absolute rent is an additional deduction from surplus-value possible because: (1) Landownership prevents capital from freely entering agriculture - landowners can keep land idle unless rent is paid. (2) Agriculture historically had lower organic composition than industry, producing above-average surplus-value per capital invested. (3) Land monopoly prevents agricultural surplus-value from entering general profit rate equalization, allowing landowners to capture this excess as rent. Absolute rent represents pure monopoly income - the landowner contributes nothing productive but extracts tribute for permitting use of a natural condition.

instruction: Why does Marx say the 'trinity formula' (capital-profit, land-rent, labour-wages) is the complete mystification of capitalist relations?
response: The trinity formula presents three apparently independent sources of wealth: capital produces profit, land produces rent, labour produces wages. Marx shows this is maximum mystification because: (1) It treats revenue forms as if they originated from fundamentally different sources rather than all deriving from labour. (2) It naturalizes social relations - capital and land appear as productive independent of their social form. (3) It conceals exploitation - workers seem to receive equivalent for their labour while capitalists and landowners receive returns on 'factors' they contribute. (4) Value and surplus-value disappear entirely from view. (5) Class relations vanish - instead of exploiters and exploited, we see cooperating factor-owners. The formula represents 'the religion of everyday life' under capitalism, inverting reality completely.

instruction: How does Marx analyze the credit system's role in capitalist development?
response: The credit system serves contradictory functions: (1) It accelerates accumulation by concentrating scattered money-capital for deployment by industrial capitalists. (2) It reduces circulation costs by substituting credit instruments for actual money. (3) It enables expansion beyond the limits of individual capital. (4) It centralizes capital through joint-stock companies, separating ownership from management. (5) It extends capitalist relations internationally. However, credit also intensifies contradictions: it enables overproduction by financing output beyond market capacity, creates chains of debt obligations that collapse in crises, and produces purely speculative activity divorced from production. Marx sees credit as both the main lever for developing capitalism toward socialization of production and the mechanism through which crises become more violent.

instruction: What is the significance of joint-stock companies in Marx's analysis of capital?
response: Joint-stock companies represent 'the abolition of capital as private property within the framework of capitalist production itself' - a transitional form pointing toward socialized production. They show: (1) The functioning capitalist becomes a mere manager, while ownership separates into passive shareholding. (2) Social capital (pooled from many owners) replaces individual capital. (3) Production becomes explicitly social even as appropriation remains private. (4) The 'merely managing' director receives 'wages of superintendence' while shareholders receive dividends as passive rentiers. (5) The fiction that profit equals 'entrepreneurial wages' collapses when directors are paid employees. Marx sees joint-stock companies as capitalism preparing its own supersession - demonstrating that capitalists as individuals are dispensable while the social organization of production they've developed is the foundation for socialism.

instruction: What is Marx's concept of 'fictitious capital'?
response: Fictitious capital is capital that exists only as titles to revenue - shares, bonds, government securities - representing claims on future surplus-value rather than actual capital in production. Government bonds are pure fiction: they represent past spending (often on wars) whose value is long consumed, yet they trade as 'capital' earning interest. Share prices fluctuate independently of the actual capital they nominally represent, rising with expected profits or falling with interest rate changes. The same real capital thus exists twice: once as actual productive capital and again as tradeable securities. In financial crises, fictitious capital values collapse toward (or below) the underlying real capital values, revealing the illusory nature of speculative paper wealth. Fictitious capital expresses capital fetishism in pure form.

instruction: How does Marx analyze the role of bank capital in the capitalist system?
response: Banks concentrate idle money-capital from all classes and make it available to productive and commercial capitalists. Bank capital consists of: (1) Cash and precious metals. (2) Securities (government bonds, shares). (3) Bills of exchange and loans representing credit extended. Most of this is fictitious capital - paper titles rather than real productive capital. Banks economize on metallic circulation by creating credit instruments, accelerating turnover and enabling expanded production beyond actual money supply. However, banks also amplify crises: in boom times, they extend credit freely, facilitating overproduction; in crisis, they contract credit suddenly, turning liquidity problems into insolvencies. Bank capital represents the 'centralization of money-capital' that both advances and destabilizes capitalist development.

instruction: How does the Communist Party of the Philippines analyze the current US-China rivalry?
response: The CPP condemns both the US and China as imperialist powers violating Philippine sovereignty. They were partners propagating neoliberalism for four decades but are now increasingly in conflict. US policymakers concluded that China exploited its two-tiered economy (state and private capitalism) for strategic goals, manipulated trade and currency, used export surpluses to take over markets, and stole US technology. However, the US government blames China partly to mislead Americans about the crisis of overproduction, obfuscating its own follies: overspending on military forces and wars of aggression, outsourcing manufacturing to China at American workers' expense, increasing investments in China after 1989, and allowing China large trade surpluses. The worsening inter-imperialist contradictions signal conditions favorable for revolutionary advances, as imperialist powers become engrossed in internal problems and overextend themselves globally.

instruction: What is the CPP's policy on marriage and family relations for party members?
response: The CPP has promulgated a Code on Family Relations. When a Party member intends to court someone, they must inform their Party branch. If the other party is not a member, efforts are made to develop them at least to candidate-member status before marriage is approved, so the couple can be helpful to each other in revolutionary work. While romantic/sexual attraction is assumed, relations must be 'developed and raised to the level of proletarian class love and revolutionary partnership.' Marriage among Party members is monogamous, with recourse to divorce if incompatibility, infidelity, or political betrayal is proven; care of children is considered. Among masses in guerrilla fronts, responsible officials of the people's democratic government, CPP, NPA, or mass organizations can officiate marriages, though couples may also marry through religious organizations or step outside to hold ceremonies letting relatives and friends attend.

instruction: How did the Communist Party of the Philippines assess Duterte's initial offer of peace negotiations?
response: Duterte had a record as a bureaucrat capitalist and unreliable ally of the NDFP in Mindanao. When he became presidential candidate, he offered to form a coalition government with the NDFP and unconditionally amnesty all political prisoners. The legal democratic movement's Makabayan Bloc didn't support him but Grace Poe. Still, he offered peace negotiations as president. However, he didn't issue general amnesty but offered cabinet appointments to 'entrap the CPP in capitulation.' Only 19 prisoners were released while he tried to obtain indefinite ceasefire in exchange. The CPP and NDFP had to follow united front policy - they couldn't dismiss Duterte's offer without exposing him first, or they would 'appear as the bellicose party' and offend peace advocates. The negotiations effectively collapsed by April 2017 when his true hostility was exposed.

instruction: How did Ghassan Kanafani connect Zionism to colonialism and imperialism?
response: Kanafani demonstrated that Zionism is a reactionary ideology that 'fitted exactly the ambitions of British colonialism' and later American imperialism. He cited how Weizmann wrote to Lord Rhodes (after whom Rhodesia was named) asking to learn 'the style in which the colonialists in Rhodesia succeeded in establishing the racial society there.' He noted the parallel development between South Africa since 1910 and Israel's laws between 1948-1960. After 22 years, Israel proved to be 'nothing except a colonialist state playing the role of a tool for American imperialists.' Oil companies built military factories in Israel while extracting profits from Arab oil. Israel represents 'the fortress of imperialism and colonialism' in the region - not merely a home for Jews, but 'the base of imperialism.'

instruction: How did Stalin respond to comparisons between himself and Peter the Great?
response: Stalin rejected the comparison as 'absurd.' He acknowledged Peter the Great did much to 'elevate the landlord class and develop the rising merchant class' and to 'create and strengthen the national State of the landlords and merchants,' but emphasized this 'was effected at the cost of the peasant serf who was bled white.' Stalin distinguished his own task: 'I am merely a pupil of Lenin, and my aim is to be a worthy pupil of his. The task to which I have devoted my life is to elevate another class—the working class. That task is not to strengthen any national State, but to strengthen a socialist State—and that means an international State.' He concluded: 'As to Lenin and Peter the Great, the latter was but a drop in the sea—Lenin was a whole ocean.'

instruction: Does Marxism deny the role of great personalities in history according to Stalin?
response: Stalin called this a 'vulgarisation of Marxism,' stating: 'Marxism does not deny that prominent personalities play an important role, nor the fact that history is made by people.' He cited Marx's Poverty of Philosophy where 'it is people who make history.' However, 'people do not make history according to their own fancy or the promptings of their imagination. Every new generation encounters definite conditions already existing, ready-made.' Great people 'are worth anything at all only to the extent that they correctly understand these conditions and know how to alter them. If they fail to understand these conditions and try to change them according to their own fancies, they will put themselves in a quixotic position.' People must not be contrasted to conditions—they make history only insofar as they correctly understand and change conditions.

instruction: Did Stalin believe Soviet power was maintained through fear and intimidation?
response: Stalin rejected this view: 'You are mistaken. Do you think it possible to maintain power and enjoy the support of millions for a period of 14 years by methods of intimidation and terror? No, that is impossible.' He noted that tsarism 'knew better than any other how to intimidate' with European bourgeois assistance, 'yet the policy of intimidation led to the collapse of tsarism.' The Romanovs' 300-year rule included rebellions of Stenka Razin, Pugachev, the Decembrists, 1905, and February 1917. Soviet workers and peasants are not 'submissive and intimidated' - the old image of 'Russian laziness' came from idle landlords in Paris, not from workers 'who in a short period of time made three revolutions.' The 90% who are workers and peasants 'stand for the Soviet government because that regime furthers the fundamental interests of the workers and peasants. This is the basis for the stability of the Soviet government.'

instruction: What did Stalin say about equalitarianism and Marxian socialism?
response: Stalin stated that socialism 'under which everybody would receive the same pay, an equal quantity of meat, bread, wear the same clothes and receive the same goods in equal quantities—such a kind of socialism is unknown to Marxism.' Until classes are abolished and work transforms from a means of existence into 'voluntary labour performed for the benefit of society, people will continue to be paid in accordance with the amount of labour performed.' The Marxian formula for socialism (the first stage of communism) is: 'From each according to his capacity, to each according to the work he performs.' Only in the highest phase of communism will the principle be: 'From each according to his capacity, to each according to his needs.' Stalin called equalitarianism 'entirely alien to Marxian socialism,' rooted in 'the mentality of the peasant, the psychology of share and share alike, the psychology of primitive peasant communism.'

instruction: How did Stalin explain Soviet respect for American efficiency?
response: Stalin clarified: 'We have no particular respect for everything American. But we respect the efficiency the Americans display in everything—in industry, in technology, in literature and in life.' He noted Americans have 'a healthy attitude towards work and towards practical affairs' and 'simplicity of approach.' Despite being 'a highly developed capitalist country, their industrial methods and productive habits contain something of the democratic spirit' unlike 'old European capitalist countries where the haughty spirit of the feudal aristocracy still prevails.' In America, 'a country of free colonists, without a landlord class, and without aristocrats,' it is difficult 'to distinguish the engineer from the worker by mere outward appearance.' However, Stalin emphasized: 'if we are to speak of our sympathies toward any particular nation, then of course, we must speak of our sympathy for the Germans.'

instruction: What did Stalin say about Bolshevik politicians keeping their word?
response: In discussing Soviet-Polish negotiations, Stalin explained: 'We are politicians of a peculiar breed, if you like. There are politicians who promise a thing one day, and next day either forget all about it, or else deny that they promised any such thing, and do so without blushing. That is not our way. Whatever we do abroad inevitably becomes known inside the country, to all workers and peasants. If we declared one thing, and did another, we should forfeit our authority.' This accountability to the working class meant Bolsheviks had to maintain consistency between words and deeds. When they declared willingness to sign a non-aggression pact with Poland, 'it is not a mere empty statement; it means that we actually do want to sign such a pact.'

instruction: How did Stalin distinguish Soviet socialism from fascist 'state socialism'?
response: Stalin rejected the term 'state socialism' as inexact, noting it usually describes systems where 'a certain part of wealth passes into the hands of the state while in the overwhelming majority of cases the works, factories and the land remain the property of private persons.' Soviet society is fundamentally different: 'the private ownership of the factories, works, the land, the banks and the transport system has been abolished and public ownership put in its place.' Neither Italian fascism nor German National-Socialism has anything in common with this because 'the private ownership of the factories and works, of the land, the banks, transport, etc., has remained intact, and, therefore, capitalism remains in full force in Germany and in Italy.' The foundation of Soviet society is public property - state (national) and cooperative (collective farm) property.

instruction: How did Stalin respond to claims that socialism restricts personal liberty?
response: Stalin rejected this: 'Your question suggests that socialist society denies personal liberty. That is not true.' He acknowledged that building socialism required sacrifice: 'If one wants to build a house one saves up money, cuts down consumption for a time, otherwise the house would never be built.' But the purpose was opposite to restricting liberty: 'We did not build this society in order to restrict personal liberty but in order that the human individual may feel really free. We built it for the sake of real personal liberty, liberty without quotation marks.' He asked rhetorically: 'It is difficult for me to imagine what personal liberty is enjoyed by an unemployed person, who goes about hungry, and cannot find employment. Real liberty can exist only where exploitation has been abolished, where there is no oppression of some by others, where there is no unemployment and poverty, where a man is not haunted by the fear of being tomorrow deprived of work, of home and of bread.'

instruction: Why did Stalin argue the Soviet single-party system differs from fascist single-party systems?
response: Stalin argued that the single Communist Party reflects the absence of antagonistic classes in Soviet society: 'Our society consists exclusively of free toilers of town and country - workers, peasants, intellectuals. Each of these strata may have its special interests and express them by means of the numerous public organisations that exist. But since there are no classes, since the dividing lines between classes have been obliterated... there can be no soil for the creation of contending parties. Where there are not several classes there cannot be several parties, for a party is part of a class.' In contrast, 'under National-Socialism there is also only one party. But nothing will come of this fascist one party system. The point is that in Germany, capitalism and classes have remained, the class struggle has remained and will force itself to the surface in spite of everything, even in the struggle between parties which represent antagonistic classes, just as it did in Spain.'

instruction: Could American democracy and the Soviet system coexist according to Stalin?
response: Stalin stated: 'American democracy and the Soviet system may peacefully exist side by side and compete with each other. But one cannot evolve into the other. The Soviet system will not evolve into American democracy, or vice versa. We can peacefully exist side by side if we do not find fault with each other over every trifling matter.' This represented a position of peaceful coexistence between different social systems while maintaining that each represented a distinct path - the Soviet socialist path would not become capitalist democracy, nor would American capitalism transform into socialism through gradual evolution. Competition between the two systems could occur without military conflict.

instruction: Why did Stalin argue Roosevelt's New Deal could not achieve socialism?
response: Stalin acknowledged Roosevelt's 'outstanding personal qualities, initiative, courage and determination' but argued the New Deal could not fundamentally transform society because 'the banks, the industries, the large enterprises, the large farms are not in Roosevelt's hands. All these are private property.' The capitalist state 'does not deal much with economy in the strict sense of the word; the latter is not in the hands of the State. On the contrary, the State is in the hands of capitalist economy.' Even if Roosevelt tried to satisfy workers' interests at capitalists' expense, 'the latter will put another president in his place. The capitalists will say: Presidents come and presidents go, but we go on forever.' Without abolishing private property in means of production, 'it is impossible to create planned economy' - capitalism would preserve its inherent anarchy and crises.

instruction: How did Stalin respond to Wells' view that class divisions were oversimplified?
response: Stalin insisted that 'first of all mankind is divided into rich and poor, into property owners and exploited; and to abstract oneself from this fundamental division and from the antagonism between poor and rich means abstracting oneself from the fundamental fact.' While acknowledging intermediate strata exist - 'the technical intelligentsia, small landowners, artisans, small traders' - these 'either take the side of one or the other of these two conflicting classes, or else take up a neutral or semi-neutral position.' But 'it is not these people who decide the fate of a country, but the toiling masses, who produce all the things society requires.' The propertied class 'owns the banks, the factories, the mines, transport' and strives 'to subordinate every collective to their will,' while the exploited class 'is compelled to live by selling its labour power to the capitalists.'

instruction: What role did Stalin assign to the technical intelligentsia in social transformation?
response: Stalin acknowledged the technical intelligentsia 'can, under certain conditions, perform miracles and greatly benefit mankind' but rejected the idea they could 'play an independent historical role.' He explained: 'The engineer, the organiser of production does not work as he would like to, but as he is ordered, in such a way as to serve the interests of his employers.' While some individuals 'have awakened from the intoxication of capitalism,' most cannot 'break away from their employers and begin reconstructing the world.' Stalin asked: 'in order to transform the world it is necessary to have political power... What can those, even with the best intentions in the world, do if they are unable to raise the question of seizing power?' Only 'a great class which will take the place of the capitalist class' can transform society - 'Big ships go on long voyages.'

instruction: How does the CIA justify overthrowing democratically elected governments?
response: Former CIA Latin America division chief Duane Clarridge, in a 2015 interview with John Pilger, explicitly articulated the doctrine. When asked if it was 'okay to overthrow a democratically elected government' like Salvador Allende's in Chile, Clarridge responded bluntly: 'It depends on what your national security interests are.' When pressed about what right the US has to intervene in other countries, he stated: 'National security interests.' Pilger noted this amounts to a 'divine right' since 'the people that you do it to have no say.' Clarridge's response: 'Yeah, well, that's just tough. We are gonna protect ourselves, and we're gonna go on protecting ourselves, 'cause we end up protecting all of you.' This reveals how 'national security' functions as an infinitely elastic justification for imperialism.

instruction: What did a former CIA official say about the crimes committed under Pinochet's dictatorship?
response: Duane Clarridge, who headed the CIA's Latin American division in the early 1980s, displayed remarkable callousness about Pinochet's victims in a 2015 interview. When John Pilger mentioned the thousands who were 'disappeared and murdered,' Clarridge responded: 'Thousands? You count 'em. What thousands?' and 'Don't talk to me about truth commissions.' When Pilger mentioned seeing victims' names in Santiago's cemetery, Clarridge simply denied the scale: 'There aren't thousands. There aren't thousands, sir.'
